article_title: Corker Carves Out a Pivotal Role on Iran Nuclear Deal
article_text:
WASHINGTON—When 47 Republican senators sent a letter last month to Iran’s leaders panning U.S.-led nuclear talks, Sen. Bob Corker (R., Tenn.) didn’t even consider signing it.

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had his own plans: He didn’t want to risk undercutting bipartisan support for his legislation requiring President Barack Obama to submit any final deal with Iran to Congress for its review.

The...

twitter.description: White House officials view Sen. Bob Corker as someone they can work with as they try to sell the Iran nuclear framework, even though the Republican wants Congress to play a larger role in reviewing any deal.
twitter.creator: @kristinapet

article_metadata.author: Kristina Peterson
article_metadata.article.origheadline: Corker Carves Out a Pivotal Role on Iran Nuclear Deal

article_summary:
WASHINGTON—When 47 Republican senators sent a letter last month to Iran’s leaders panning U.S.-led nuclear talks, Sen. Bob Corker (R., Tenn.) didn’t even consider signing it.
The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had his own plans: He didn’t want to risk undercutting bipartisan support for his legislation requiring President Barack Obama to submit any final deal with Iran to Congress for its review.
